habitat_description:
Antrozous pallidus inhabits desert vegetation dominated by cacti (Kuenzi and Morrison, 2003; Frick et al., 2009); desert scrub (O’Farrell and Bradley, 1970; LaVal, 1973; Worthington, 1991; Szewczak et al., 1998; Kuenzi et al., 1999; Kuenzi and Morrison, 2003; Lenhart et al., 2010); xeric shrub grassland of saltbush, rabbitbrush, and mesquite (Jones, 1965); desert-grassland (O’Shea and Vaughan, 1977; Bell, 1982; Worthington, 1991; Lenhart et al., 2010); semi-arid desert with sagebrush, juniper, and grasses (Lewis, 1994; Rambaldini and Brigham, 2011); sagebrush habitats (Worthington, 1991; Chapman et al., 1994; Rambaldini and Brigham, 2011); sparse grassland with scattered ponderosa pine (Chapman et al., 1994); pine-oak woodlands with gambel oak, juniper, and buckbrush (Morrell et al., 1999); agricultural fields (Ball, 1998; Ball, 2002); and vineyards (Rambaldini and Brigham, 2011).

The species has demonstrated inconsistent affinities toward other habitat types, with some studies showing a clear preference for riparian deciduous forest (Fenton et al., 1980; Williams et al., 2006; Bucci et al., 2010), for example, while others reveal avoidance of this habitat type (LaVal, 1973; Kuenzi et al., 1999). Similar patterns exist for: mesquite bosques (Williams et al., 2006; Bucci et al., 2010); pinyon-juniper woodland (Jones, 1965; Ports and Bradley, 1996; Szewczak et al., 1998; Kuenzi et al., 1999); and Sierran and coastal California mixed conifer forests (Orr, 1954; Morrell et al., 1999; Zielinski and Gellman, 1999; Baker et al., 2008).

A. pallidus prefers low canopy cover (Baker et al., 2008) and it avoids marshes (Williams et al., 2006).

The pallid bat roosts in: rock crevices in boulders or in cliffs (Finley, 1954; Hirshfeld et al., 1977; O’Shea and Vaughan, 1977; Chapman et al., 1994; Ports and Bradley, 1996; Ball, 1998; Ball, 2002); on and in trees (Hirshfeld et al., 1977; Ball, 1998; Ball, 2002; Baker et al., 2008); buildings (Beck and Rudd, 1960; Hirshfeld et al., 1977; Bell, 1982; Szewczak et al., 1998; Gitzen et al., 2002; Lenhart et al., 2010) under bridges (Beck and Rudd, 1960; Davis and Cockrum, 1962; Geluso and Mink, 2006); in caves (Port and Bradley, 1996; Ball, 1998; Ball, 2002); and mines (Port and Bradley, 1996). The species hibernates in caves and mines (Port and Bradley, 1996), but due to the number of winter capture in New Mexico, Geluso (2007) posited that the species may not be an obligate hibernator throughout its range.

Distances between roosts and foraging areas can be as much as 8.5 km (Ball, 1998; Ball, 2002).

Elevations at which the pallid bat is found range from near sea level in California to nearly 2450 m in New Mexico (Black, 1974). In British Columbia, maximum elevations were around 500 m (Chapman et al., 1994).
